title: What is leukemia? - Danilo Allegra and Dania Puggioni

multiple-choice.question: What makes cancer difficult to cure?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a single illness with a straightforward treatment

options.label: B
options.text: It is a family of over 100 diseases occurring in different types of cells

multiple-choice.question: Which type of cancer afflicts children more than any other type?
Where do stem cells in the bone marrow differentiate into different types of blood cells?
What is the function of white blood cells in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To carry oxygen from the lungs to all tissues

options.label: B
options.text: To help stop bleeding by sticking to damaged blood vessels

options.label: C
options.text: To patrol the body and destroy potentially harmful invaders

multiple-choice.question: What happens to cells with compromised DNA?

options.label: B
options.text: They replicate uncontrollably and lose their original function

multiple-choice.question: Why is leukemia the most common childhood cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by many DNA modifications

options.label: B
options.text: It is caused by just one or two DNA modifications

multiple-choice.question: What happens when leukemic cells reproduce in the blood and bone marrow?

options.label: A
options.text: They create more space and resources for healthy cells

options.label: B
options.text: They take up all available space and resources

multiple-choice.question: How are leukemic cells typically treated?

options.label: B
options.text: Through chemotherapy and other treatments that kill cells inside the body

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential side effect of chemotherapy for leukemia?

options.label: B
options.text: It kills healthy cells, such as those found in hair follicles or intestines

multiple-choice.question: What is required for a successful bone marrow transplant?

options.label: A
options.text: Antigen compatibility between the donor and recipient

options.label: B
options.text: Blood type compatibility between the donor and recipient

options.label: C
options.text: Tissue type compatibility between the donor and recipient

options.label: D
options.text: Organ compatibility between the donor and recipient

title: Why neutrinos matter - Sílvia Bravo Gallart

multiple-choice.question: What are the ghost particles mentioned in the transcript called?
What is a unique characteristic of neutrinos?

options.label: A
options.text: They are highly affected by magnetic fields

options.label: B
options.text: They can be subdivided into other particles

options.label: C
options.text: They hardly ever interact with anything

options.label: D
options.text: They are the largest known building blocks of the universe

multiple-choice.question: Where are neutrinos produced?

options.label: C
options.text: Almost everywhere, including the human body, the sun, and the Earth's atmosphere

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the IceCube neutrino telescope in Antarctica?

options.label: C
options.text: To detect neutrinos and learn about the universe's most extreme environments

options.label: D
options.text: To study the sun's nuclear reactions

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists at IceCube detect neutrinos?

options.label: A
options.text: By observing the light emitted by neutrinos

options.label: B
options.text: By putting a huge volume of pure transparent material in their path and waiting for a neutrino to collide with an atom

options.label: C
options.text: By using magnetic fields to attract neutrinos

options.label: D
options.text: By using nuclear reactors to generate neutrinos

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a high-energy neutrino collides with a molecule of ice at IceCube?

options.label: A
options.text: It absorbs the neutrino without any reaction

options.label: B
options.text: It releases a large amount of heat

options.label: C
options.text: It shoots off sparks of charged subatomic particles that travel faster than light

multiple-choice.question: What do the scientists at IceCube use to amplify the signal from the charged particles?
What is the significance of the data collected by IceCube?

options.label: A
options.text: It will help scientists understand the Earth's atmosphere

options.label: B
options.text: It will reveal the secrets of the sun's nuclear reactions

options.label: C
options.text: It will help scientists understand the universe's most extreme environments and the origins of cosmic rays

multiple-choice.question: What is the age that we are currently in, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: The age of cosmic ray research

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome of the research conducted by IceCube and other neutrino telescopes?

options.label: A
options.text: A complete understanding of the universe's most extreme environments

options.label: C
options.text: Revelations about the universe's most violent and energetic phenomena

options.label: D
options.text: A solution to the mystery of dark matter

title: How to unboil an egg - Eleanor Nelsen

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the proteins in an egg when heat is added?

options.label: A
options.text: The proteins become more rigid and compact.

options.label: B
options.text: The proteins unfold, uncoil, and unwind.

options.label: D
options.text: The proteins start to break down into smaller molecules.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when heat disrupts the chemical bonds holding the proteins together, allowing them to unfold?
According to the principle of microscopic reversibility, what can theoretically happen to egg proteins that have seized up?

options.label: C
options.text: They can theoretically "unhappen" and return to their original state.

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists "unboil" egg whites in a laboratory setting?

options.label: A
options.text: By adding more heat to the solution.

options.label: C
options.text: By dissolving the egg whites in water with urea and spinning the solution at high speed.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a special type of cooking oil.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of adding urea to the solution of egg whites?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the velocity of the solution.

options.label: B
options.text: To create sheer stresses in the solution.

options.label: C
options.text: To act as a lubricant and allow the proteins to glide past each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the difference in velocity between the solution nearest the wall and the solution closer to the middle?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a uniform velocity throughout the solution.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the proteins to become more entangled.

options.label: C
options.text: It creates sheer stresses that stretch and contract the proteins.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the solution.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential application of the "unboiling" method in the pharmaceutical industry?

options.label: B
options.text: To create new types of cooking oil.

options.label: C
options.text: To refold proteins that are stuck in tangled aggregates, making it easier and cheaper to produce certain pharmaceuticals.

options.label: D
options.text: To denature proteins in food products.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't the "unboiling" method be used with a whole egg in its shell?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the solution cannot spread throughout a cylindrical chamber.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the eggshell is too hard to penetrate.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the method only works with egg whites.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the method requires a special type of cooking oil.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between boiling an egg and other types of cooking, such as frying?

options.label: A
options.text: Boiling an egg changes the chemical identity of the proteins, while frying does not.

options.label: B
options.text: Boiling an egg does not change the chemical identity of the proteins, while frying does.

options.label: C
options.text: Boiling an egg is a faster cooking method than frying.

options.label: D
options.text: Boiling an egg is a more expensive cooking method than frying.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the reaction that occurs when cooking methods, such as frying, make chemical changes to sugars and proteins?

options.label: C
options.text: They have higher accident rates and are worse at using tools designed for right-handed people
